title: Replacement knob and foot for camera tripod mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I broke the foot off the special bolt that holds this mount to the side of a tripod and ended up buying a new one. However while cleaning things out I came across the old one and realized it was repairable.  
You can guess which one in the picture is the one I repaired, heh. It would have been a 20$ savings. I'll probably give the spare away to a friend.  
I am posting this here as an example of what a 3D printer can do that is useful when your wife/husband says "Ok, it's neat, but what's it GOOD for?".  
And maybe the files will be useful to someone else somday, who knows.
Print, hot glue onto a bolt, tighten.

author: zenmojo

print_settings.Notes:: Just a solid block, you could test any slicer profile (speed, infill, resolution...)

description.text:
This is a basic steps/mm calibration board, measuring 40x40x4mm (XYZ) and with X and Y axes marked. Freecad, STL and GCode (sliced with Cura) files are provided, plus a LibreOffice Calc spreadsheet that I use to store my custom settings and to calibrate (fine tune) "steps/mm" (M92) parameters.

After printing it on my Mp Select mini 3D Printer, I measure it with a digital caliper and transfer the values to the spreadsheet (yellow column). The results are displayed on the green column. Rinse and repeat ;-)

Printer:

Monoprice Select mini / Malyan M200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Just a solid block, you could test any slicer profile (speed, infill, resolution...)

Update: Uploaded V2 of the simple filament guide, this should make it easier to pull the guide out when necessary.  
--  
I have tried a few versions of Brook Drumm's filament guide, from the laser cut one shipped with my kit to a customized plastic guide found here on thingiverse. Even after making my own modifications to make the fit better, none was quite secure enough to keep the filament straight or keep the filament from buckling.  
I decided that a block to sit INSIDE the assembly would fix the issue - Absolutely secure and impossible for the filament to get off track. I've run a few prints off since making this and have not had any binding issues.

description.text:
This is a printable model of the Muncaster S3 CNC machine

I'm going to be producing some of these models in the form of desk ornaments, card holders, phone holders and key fobs. I thought that some of you may like them.

The S3 is a 3 axis, quiet, dust free, high precision, design studio CNC machine that I'm involved with. It fits through office doors and runs on a domestic supply. We have plans for a hybrid machine with metal deposition and removal combined and 4 / 5 Axis machines. The VuiPort User Interface is like nothing you've ever seen on a CNC machine.

We're crowd funding at the moment. Anyone who's interested should pop along to muncastertechnologies.com for details.

title: Zeldathon Recovery Triforce Bas Relief Ring
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
While watching #Zeldathon Recovery, I made a ring with an opposing Triforce design.

If you enjoy this design, please make a donation to Zeldathon! Please mention where you came from in the comments. If you're not sure how much to give, I recommend $3.00 as a good starting point. (Or $3.14 if you're nerdy.)

Photos are of a size 14 ring, 9mm high. I've also included some other sizes in case you don't want to use the Customizer.

Printer:

Rapide Lite 200 v1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm (recommended)

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Sliced with Cura, printed in silver PLA. My best results came from printing with an 0.1mm resolution, although it can also be printed at 0.2 for fitting samples.
After printing, you'll want to clean up the print a little bit with a knife, just enough to make sure there aren't whiskers or bumps on the inside of the ring.

This design originated and ended in OpenSCAD.

Fun fact: the Triforce is made by subtracting a rotated cylinder of diameter D from a cylinder with diameter 2D... both cylinders are rendered with a "number of fragments" of 3, which reduces them to triangular prisms.

Customization

Make sure to experiment with the Advanced Options if you want to change the ring's size or fine-tune other parameters.

Troubleshooting

If you are having trouble getting the ring to stick to the raft, you may need to experiment with "Thinnest Layer" in Advanced Options.

Licensing

You are granted a Creative Commons Attribution-Non-Commercial-ShareAlike License.

If you upload your design to Thingiverse, please use the "Remix" feature.

If you upload your design elsewhere, please link to this page or pikaworx.com.

I reserve the right to negotiate special licensing.

this is a holder for the bernie simple extruder.

You need to drill 3 new holes in the holder(3 mm) for the fixing in davinci.

the two holes for the extruder have to be drilled to 3mm(2 to 3 mm) . At the moment the holes are still manually since it is a first draft . But this is not a problem

.you need 5 m3x20 mm screws an nuts.

This is a initial design for a strength test, it is expected to break at around 40kg using ABS.
The specimen should break at the middle section.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100 %

Notes:

Print at full infill in order to obtain high reproduceability (The prints are small and will not require much material anyway)
The prints should be done at the optimal temperature for your material, test this first, for example with the heat tower.
Print at least five vertically and horizontally in order to get a reasonable sample size.

Design objectives

The idea of the design do a ultimate tensile strength test of your filament to better understand properties and thus be able to create better designs.
The specimen is designed to be able to be printed vertically and horizontally without supports as well as to break on the midpoint.
It was also a design objective to create a specimen that would break under a reasonably low force so the experiments are reproduceable at home.

Changelog

Changes made to the design will be posted here, it is intended to be frozen soon so testing can be started.

Edit 1:

Attachment holes has been shrunk to avoid stress concentrations.

title: Robo 3D Full Graphics LCD Swivel Riser Feet

description.text:
This was designed similarly to Mike Kelly's: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:681887, with a few modifications of course!

The Riser Feet are working great and do not need any fixes. They are built to be used with the bottom cover, but would probably work without it as well. They also use the existing holes of the bottom cover for mounting. May need to increase the height where the screws are, if you do not have the bottom cover, or just use a washer/spacer.

You will need to get a few longer screws for the Rise Feet as the standard screws are a little short. I don't remember the exact size, #10 - 1" Long I think.

I have uploaded STL, SolidWorks, STEP, and IGES files so you can edit if need be. I am not going to post the STL files of the LCD Case until I verify it.

Since my first LCD Case did not turn out the way I wanted, I decided to redesign it but I have not printed yet. The LCD Case is for a Sainsmart Full Graphics LCD. Which is why this thing is a work in progress until I print the LCD Case again.

So far this has been a super fun project, and it makes my Robo R1+ look pretty sweet!

If anyone wants a modification, just let me know and I will see what I can do.

EDIT

I have finished printing my new rev'd LCD case for the SainSmart Controller and everything fits perfectly. This is no longer a work in progress since I have uploaded all the files need to create this thing. And I have verified they all work with my setup at least.

I have removed all old files and uploaded all the updated files. This includes all SolidWorks, STL, STEP, and IGES files. The Riser Feet have not changed. I also completely redesigned the way the case is modeled. Which, I think, looks better, fits better, and is easier to install.

6 screws are definitely not needed to install the LCD, I put them in because I had them laying around. Also the Front fits so snug that you honestly wouldn't even need to screw the Back to the Front.

Don't forget to Like and Upload your Make!!!

EDIT

If you would like this same setup but have a RepRap Full Graphics LCD or 2004 LCD, I have remixed to fit those versions:

RepRap Full Graphics LCD Remix: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1773140).

2004 LCD: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1825916/

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

You will need to use supports under the Mount Holes for the Riser Feet. You should not need supports in the Tunnel of the LCD Swivel Riser. You will definitely need supports for the LCD Back, but should not need supports for the LCD Front if you print with the face on the bed.

Print the LCD Case the way I have them oriented to not need supports for the Front.

Infill for the Front, will need to be around 60% to fill the button extrusion. Otherwise it will be hollow, which I'm sure would be fine.

I use S3D for slicing. For the supports on the Back, I adjusted the Max Overhang Angle to 70 degrees instead of 45 degrees. This removes a ton of unneeded supports and basically only puts the supports in places parallel with the bed.

Hardware

(1) SainSmart Full Graphics LCD Controller with Cables (obviously)
(4) #10 - 1" Long Rounded Head Screws
(8) #4 - 1/2" Long Flat Head Screws

description.text: 12 5-sided polygons that fit together to form a dodecahedron.  This is probably the smallest buckyball that you could realistically make.  There a solid version, and a "wired version", which is way way easier to put together.  This is to mess with you geometry-lovers out there.

Version 12 is what you want.  This will produce 3 self-contained shapes.  You can use them separately, or hang one inside of each other.  There are three triangles with holes in it which should let you attach fishing wire on.
File 7 should have everything fit together correctly, and contains 3 different sizes!  If everything works out correctly, the smaller ones should be able to hang and rotate within the larger ones!
Files 3 and 4 are earlier drafts.  They will fit together correctly, but the shapes are irregular and it will be much harder to assemble.  You'll need to have one right side facing and other other reversed.

comments.author: wbarber69

comments.text: Recently installed the heated bed on mine. What is it that you are using to shield/reflect the heat under the bed? Great design on the cable chain. Is your printer elevated or did you drill/cut a hole to allow wires to go in the backside?
comments.author: D_Rogers

comments.text: The heated bed kit comes with the reflective layer.  this will work on the printer without any modifications other than a screw hole on the bed support
comments.author: D_Rogers

comments.text: Is it the Printrbot heated bed kit? I just ordered mine and it didn't come with anything reflective.
comments.author: wbarber69

comments.text: Then you should complain!  lol but for real that foil crap is useless and it doesn't stay on so it drags under the bed all the time and I have to use tape to hold it on.
comments.author: D_Rogers

comments.text: Ha. Maybe they figured out it was more of a pain than it's worth and stopped including it. Thanks for answering my newb questions.
comments.author: wbarber69

comments.text: is this for the extended bed?
comments.author: orangeju1ce

comments.text: Yes
comments.author: orangeju1ce

comments.text: Sweet! Thank you. But how do you mount it to the bed? It doesnt clip in place like the one on the frame part.
comments.author: Guzzi80

comments.text: The bed gets so hot underneath that anything that clips on would warp and fall off.  so I drilled a small hole in the bed bracket and use a screw and nut to hold it in place.  the bottom part also has holes for this reason
comments.author: Guzzi80

comments.text: Ok thanks man :)

description.text:
For those who love Zombicide now the new Project of Cmon and Guillotine Games is growing up at kickstarter, I'm talking about Massive Darkness and if you want to be prepared when your pledge comes home here we have a new way to manage your progress with this new Plastic Dashboard. In inspiration of the Zombicide Black Plague Dashboard, this one pretend to manage your hero exp more visualy and its because it is reusable you not need no more a sheet pad.

I hope you all enjoy more your games with this new accesory. Thanks.

PD: Massive Darkness is a game from Guillotine Games and Cool Mini Or Not

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

P3Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

This model was printed with a 0.8 mm size nozel to speed up the process. The material I chose was an ABS filament of 1.75 mm

title: Omnimac OP CC3D And Revo Anti Vibration Mount

description.text: Anti vibration mount for the open pilot CC3D and Revo flight controllers.
See PDF instructions in files

comments.text: Can you provide a version without the 4 standoffs on top so it is just flush? I plan to mount my board with a case around it so I don't need the extra height.
comments.author: Hovership

comments.text: Hi Hovership, sorry for the very slow response.  I've been in Africa for the last few months, so internet access has been difficult.  It should be an easy modification, so I'll see if I can get an updated file up within the next few days.
comments.author: Hovership

comments.text: Hey nice mount, any chance of the editable file? I have some changes id like to make.
comments.author: Kawobei

comments.text: Hi Kawobei, as requested, I've added the Rhino 3D master file.  I'd be interested to see what changes you make to it. Unfortunately I keep missing out on the Revo batches, so I have no hardware to test it with.
comments.author: Kawobei

comments.text: I tried to work out Rhino3D but i couldn't make heads or tails of it, I was just going to make the top plate start at the bottom of the dampeners that way it has a lower hight profile overall, any chance you can do that easily?
comments.author: GuyMcCaldin

comments.text: I'll put it on my to do list, but unfortunately it will likely be a while before I can work on it again.  What program do you typically model in?  I might be able to export it in a compatible format.
comments.author: Kawobei

comments.text: I use solidworks, but none of them convert over to not being 1 solid body. Its ok if I really get keen ill redraw it in SolidWorks

remixed_from.author: anarmyofnone
remixed_from.title: Solidoodle 2 anti-backlash assembly for aluminum z-axis carrier

description.text: This is V2 of my Solidoodle 2 Anti-Backlash Assembly. It's fairly similar to identical to my first version, but I've reduced the overall height so there's a little more space between the top of the nut ant the top of the z-axis screw when the bed is at the top of the z-axis.  The second photo shows the height differential, with V1 on the left and V2 on the right.

The spring I'm using has a 0.825 O.D., 0.725 I.D, and 0.05 wire thickness.  It's approximately 1.2 inches free length, and 0.300 compressed length.  This particular spring was selected simply because it was all my local hardware had on hand that met my needs.  Century Spring (centuryspring.com) carries a similar spring that looks like it will work nicely: part no. S-799.  Unfortunately, they've got a $40 minimum order so I haven't tried yet.  
When printing the upper spring retainer, I've been printing with the hex side down, and using support material inside the hex.  It might be possible to print without support material, but I haven't tried it yet.  I the future, I may try creating chamfer at the bottom of the hex instead of a flat surface in order to see how it prints without support material.  
When assembling the two halves, I usually take a small file to the side mating surfaces of the cutaways.  Ideally, you want the two halves to fit together and be able to slide vertically without binding.

author: davidgeller

description.text:
Attempt at making a plug for the nozzle slot in the flow cell on a BD FACSAria II Flow Cytometer, with the purpose of experimenting with droplet formation without a nozzle in place.

The Idea is that this blank nozzle "slug" will block any air disturbances in the flow cell that may cause the stream to be unstable while attempting droplet formation without an actual nozzle.

There are 3 variations in length included in this file: 18mm, 17mm, and 15mm. I haven't had a chance to print or test these out on the machine, so I don't know which length works, or if there are any other changes to be made.

Let me know what you find out if you do any experimenting!

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eS948f5aWiv

I took the original MaduixaCNC model and modified several parts to make it work using 12mm steel rods in place of the 8mm and LM12UU linear bearings instead of the 8mm bearings.

In addition, I also modified y-carriage-cnc and y-triangle-CNC to make them into 1 part (called y-carriage-cnc_short+X support_left and _right). It makes the connection between them stronger, I might make it bigger in the Y direction in the future to improve stability of the y carriage.

Another change is a small dip in the X carriage to accommodate the NEMA17 motor which was not possible to mount in my case because of the position of the screws.

Also made a version of the x-corner-CNC-AB with straight mounting feet to allow more accurate placement.

Also extended the Z-carriage to accommodate 2 LM12UU bearings.

The following should be taken from the original model:
2sides-corner-CNC
3sides-corner-CNC
bed-holder-CNC
universal-holder-CNC
x-drive-train-CNC
x-end-idler-CNC

I'm also adding my own design dremel holder (for some generic dremel-like machine with a round diameter of 47mm if I remember correctly) and a pen holder for drawing.

I hope I didn't miss anything, it works perfectly! I have some issues with Amp draw and my power supply, soon to be remedied :)
Very solid build, so far tested only on MDF as stock, will probably do more testing after I replace the power supply.
I'm running it with the modified Marlin (using the 2 Z outputs as Y) and interestingly found out I can run the G-Code from a Raspberry PI running Repetier-Server! So I get a webcam interface to follow my machine when I'm not there.

My best result so far, with 2 passes (rough + fine) is the title picture, I am VERY happy with the result, even though there is a slight miss in the rough part because of the power supply issue (X motor jitters when moving slowly sometimes).

Update 25-July-2016:

Created updated version of X-drivetrain, Y-carriage and Z-carriage for higher stiffness level, it greatly reduced the flexing between X and Y as well as reduced the play in the X axis motion.

The new parts are marked as _V2 at the end.

Update 27-August-2016:

Created a Nema 23 version of the y-end-motor and y-end-idler as well as x-end-idler parts.
These have been created based on the theoretical sizes so please confirm they fit when someone tries them.

Remember, you have to use the correct idler with the different motor size for the middle hole to line up.

Just realized you don't need the X-idler for Nema 23...

Update 9-SEP-2016

Added Nema23 y-carriage STL with both sides in one STL.

Update 11-SEP-2016

Split y-carriage to Left and Right.
Also fixed the normals on the Right one.

Update 16-SEP-2016

Thanks to @MAXANJLI, fixed a mistake in the Y carriages for Nema23.

Update 9-OCT-2016

Added spindle mount for 52mm Spindle, works, but can be better...

Update 3-Dec-2016

Some updates, a lot has changed since the previous version:
I replaced both Y and X threaded rod with a:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/8x500mm-Lead-Screw-Rod-T-Shape-Linear-Rail-Bar-Shaft-with-Brass-Nut-lead-screw/32636940699.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.l42jsw

Which required a edit the parts that hold the nuts for X and Y, new versions uploaded.
The maximal speed at low motor speed (high torque) is much improved, also added some endstop switches, and voila, fast homing:
https://1drv.ms/v/s!AlMOSniKVu-g1GBfAl8Pi5JcBFgv

Also made a small change in the structure with a big impact, instead of using the standoffs for the build plate, I screwed down a full plate on top of the frame.
This contributed a lot to the rigidity of the frame, still working on getting a clamping method that works well with this, currently using screws, but waiting for a T type end mill to make grooves in my build plate.

As for the spindle mount, PLA is not a good material for a mount because when the spindle warms up the PLA gets warped.
Changed it to wood + aluminum bracket.

I like how it works:
https://1drv.ms/v/s!AlMOSniKVu-g1FqZFfRhgI9U4gjy

Update January 10

I've switched over to an mpcnc structure.
Moved my electronics and some of of my trusty Maduixa with a baby heart (can't afford to have two CNC machines in my small shed).

Initial impressions are mixed. Mpcnc is much faster (belt driven) but also less rigid (belt driven :) ).
I do like the speed improvement and already have some ideas for improving rigidity.

Thanks for following this project!
I will of course continue supporting questions and requests!

description.text: Piko BLX mount for the Tomoquads Frame

This work is a part of my progress towards the Public Lab Reconfigurable Rig, work done as a part of my Autodesk Student Expert Internship at Public Lab. Check out the current Reconfigurable Rig files and instructions on Github.

This is a simple and useless roller chain made only with laser cutting.
This is made with 3mm MDF.
The center distance is 17mm.
Center of the outside chain link is square.
Center of the inside chain link is round.

You need to sand the pinion in the thickness to catch the chain.

I will redesign pinions to make it more beautiful

Step 1

Push your pins in a outside link.
you can glue the pieces.

Step 2

Insert three little pieces (round on a square) through each pins.
No glue.

Step 3

Insert an inside link on each pins.
Insert a roller and finish with an other inside link.

Step 4

Close the roller chain with an outside link.
This is a new design for a Vape station I am currently working on. It will be mounted on risers on top of the desk. Holds box mods, tube mods, juice, and spools of wire.
This is the desk it will mount to.

This work is a part of my progress towards the Public Lab Reconfigurable Rig, work done as a part of my Autodesk Student Expert Internship at Public Lab. Check out the current Reconfigurable Rig files and instructions on Github.

You can use screws or as in my case 1/8 rivets with back up washers.
Learn from my mistake and place it so that the collets don't interfere with the cabinet latch.

description.text: in order to make the Robbe U47 a static diver. It really needs a new techrack.

I created this alternative techrack for the Robbe U47 RC Submarine kit so it would fit a static diving system. Instructions:
  • Print the bulkheads
  • connect them with M6 threaded rods (78cm)
  • insert the electronics tables in the front and the rear.
  • use nuts on each side to put the bulkheads in place
    • The techrack provides mountpoints for:
  • the included Speed 550 motors
  • Receiver, LTR5.3, SBTS, Rokraft 120 ESC
  • Engel 750ml EA tank
  • 4 Carbonite Tiger2 servos
  • 6500mAh LiPo batterypack
    • Revision .2:
  • added 2 servo slots in the 2nd table
  • Added holes in the last bulkhead for the servo leads
  • made the cable guides larger so they accomodate servocables (without having to remove the plug to get them through ;) )
  • added bulkhead 5.1. The motor block can now be moved seperate from the servo table.

remixed_from.title: J-Head Bowden Delta Printer (bowden support, all metal) with microswitch

description.text:
This was supposed to be a Z probe sensor mounted directly on the Platform, before you add your hot end, in order to calibrate your delta X, Y and Z Offset and also Radius.

You need:

  • some switches between 3-6 is up to you. You can find on banggood some small switches here or long switches here
  • some soldering equipment and skill
  • and a printer of course to print this.

All the switches will be connected in parallel so when anyone is pressed, the ZProbe is triggered.

Note: Didn't finish the setup yet will update with picture and video when ready.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Rostock mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.4 nozzle, 0.2 layer height

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I used ABS, since I saw it makes a better precision part, but is shouldn't matter that much

I used the OpenScad sources from mini

I duplicated the platform file, removed what was not needed.
Measured a switch and placed it on the platform as a hollow space.
Also I made sure there were hollow corners so I can put wire through that.
I also added some room for the wire on the back, since that will be bolted to the platform.

I will see if there are problems with the current design and I might add some space in the next iteration on the same face with the micro switch for a m3 nut.

Add space for hex nut / hex screw

Just added the v2 with the hex space, and cleaned up the unneeded carriage.scad.

Merge directly into platform

I added a new version that merged it directly into the platform. you might not want to be a separate thing, but be part of your delta platform.

Note/TODO:
It can be created some sort of ring that can be attached to trigger the switches.
Maybe the holder of the extruder/hotend can have some sort of trigger mechanism.

title: Ultimaker Gopro Time-Lapse  Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Gopro mount is made for the Gopro 3 and 4 and can be used on the Ulitmaker 2 and 2+ and maybe the Ultimaker 2 Go as wel. (maybe for other printers as wel.)

I wanted to make a simple design and a design where you don’t need any other Gopro products.

A big advantage of this design is that you don’t need your protective case around your Gopro, so the side where you can plug in your cables is al clear. This is very handy if your print takes longer than the battery life of your Gopro. Just connect it to a power supply!

Video of the Gopro Mount: https://youtu.be/GBhDK7fzwiQ

After a long delay, I have finally updated this to version 1.8. Version 1.8 is mainly a bug fix version. No new features have been added, just a bunch of bugs fixed.

If you have any issues, please comment with the settings giving you issues, along with the issue you are having. This way I can duplicate it and fix the issue.

This is a work in progress, and will be updated a lot.

Version 1.8

This version is a pure bug fix version. No new features have been added.
~Fixed Straight Styles center Support Beam. Had a bug where is had a slight gap.
~Replaced the codes used to generate the stright support. The new
Version is more accurate and gives pointed edges.
~Fixed sizing issues. Old versions could be off by up to the wall thickness.
This version auto corrects it to be correct.
~Replaced the code to ensure it is the right size with a polygon shape.
Old versions used a basic cube shape and was not accurate enough to handle this.
~Replaced some code with the rounded stylegiving the edges are squared edge.
pointed corners were deformed on oval shaped brackets

Upcoming updates

~The corner angle will be able to be adjusted. this will be limited to 30-150 degrees)
This will allow you to make a slanted shelf, or even a diamond box.
~Planning on adding a couple new bracket styles (Allowing for a truely customisable bracket)

A 2-part, hinged, bolt-on holder/fixture for affixing a small packaged sensing device (in this case a custom WIMU) to a round shaft or bar allowing it to be easily attached to golf clubs, tennis racquets, pipes, cylindrical bar stock, walking sticks etc.

• Measure diameter of device to be held and cylindrical bar onto which devices will attach and modify source files accordingly. Currently the files are sized for a golf club (a mens driver) holding a 303630mm packaged item (custom WIMU)
  • Print out top and bottom half of object and clean up any rough edges.
  • Drill out hinge pivot hole on bottom part to JUST less than 3mm and top part to a bit more than 3mm.
  • Assemble the top onto the bottom part of the hinge and insert a piece of 3mm printing filament so that it passes through both top and bottom, fix in place with glue or acetone on the bottom part only Note: the top and bottom part should pivot reasonably smoothly.
  • Insert M4 Nut into recess on top part and thread M4 Bolt of appropriate length upwards through corresponding hole in bottom part and place onto shaft item before mating and bolt the 23 parts together. Note: it may be a good idea to coat the rounded recesses that correspond to the shaft with rubberised paint or foam etc. to ensure a secure fit.
  • Insert sensing device into provided void.
  • Record data with device attached to rod like item.

The lingam is often represented alongside the yoni (Sanskrit word, literally "origin" or "source" or "womb"), a symbol of the goddess or of Shakti, female creative energy. The union of lingam and yoni represents the "indivisible two-in-oneness of male and female. I create this one using FreeCad.

author: ScotchBunny

description.text:
After having my Kress 1050-1 milling motor converted to trim router with my trim router base (thing 1611593), I needed an extra power cable since the original is integrated in the gantry of my CNC table.
A Kress power cable with a special quick-action lock connector costs about 25 euros incl shipping, which is pretty expensive, so I've made the connector myself.
The quick-action lock connector is used by over 35 Kress tools

What you need:

  • This connector printed (duh..)
  • Two 6.3mm crimp automotive style connectors female (cable shoes)
  • Two M3 20mm screws with nuts
  • an redundant PC power cord
  • soldering iron
  • some hot glue

How you do it:

  • Cut of the unused connector of the power cord.
  • strip the outer mantle just far enough to be able to poke the 2 wires
    through the connector
  • crimp AND solder the wires to the cable shoes and push them back in the connector
  • use hot glue to secure the wires (and by that the cable shoes stay in place)
  • twist the outer cable a few times until the mantle reaches the strain relief
  • put the screw and bolt in and tighten

I made a version with strain relief using M3 bolt, but also have included a version
without. The latter was my first version and relies on the hot glue and your common sense :-)

I printed them upright in ABS at 0.2mm with support (which is easy to remove)

title: Teinturman 's spool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I thought that a great spool holder should have the following properties :

  • Easy to build
  • Minimal Filament use for building
  • No bearings or other parts than prints ( as it is not needed for such use !)
  • Low frictions in rotation
  • Nice design
  • The filament spool can be removed and changed with a different colour easily .
  • Can cope with multiple spool types in width, and in spool holes
  • Can stand without being screwed
  • Can be screwed on a wood platform
  • There must be some Filament guides to prevent filament going off track
  • a dust filter is needed to filter
  • can be use as a horizontal or vertical spool holder, as you wish.

Teinturman's spool Holder is my proposition to fullfill all these requirements :

The key concept is that there is no transverse axis : the bushing are rotating on each side of the spool holder, and it is possible to bend the legs to put or remove a spool easily.

Many screw holes are prepared to allow any mounting you want, and especially to mount nicely within the teinturman's enclosure :

It is possible to slide the legs in width, to adapt to small or large spool holders.

The default Bushing is 52mm diameter.
The bushing can be changed relatively easily by removing the pin. I will provide soon a parametric bushing thing , so that you can make the ones that you need.

In some cases, it would be nice to have a bushing that works with 2 sizes, but that is for future enhancements.

Note : you may want to check my enclosure for 3D printer :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1637043

and my Nema 17 Filament guide :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1647053

author: anacastillejo

title: Project: A0-TAZ - Lulzbot TAZ Style X Ends for A0-10x Printers

description.text: This project adds anti-backlash and anti-wobble similar to that found on the Lulzbot TAZ printer to the older Lulzbot A0-10x designs. It will also likely fit some Mendelmax 1.5+-ish Derivatives. With the addition of a second Acme nut, a metal spring, and the printed parts above, you should be able to eliminate any remaining wobble from your Ao-10x style printer. Please note that you will need to ensure you have clearance for the Ao-101 style Lower X end clamp if you are upgrading an older machine. Development thread is here: http://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=306

You will need the following materials: 1 X axis belt that is longer than the original one by about 20mm. I had to move the idler back to clear everything. Make sure you have enough spare belt before you take anything apart, or order one.
The existing nuts and bolts and acme nuts from your existing printer.
2 additional Right hand 3/8" -12 Acme nuts (http://www.mcmaster.com/#95155a111/=ovvhbk)
2 Handyman springs Model SP-9729 Compression Spring 5/8" x 2-34"" x .054 15.9mm x 7cm x 1.4mm) 11.72lb / 5.31kg maximum capacity spring (as found at ace hardware locally) with 15mm worth cut off at one end of each spring At least 12 Mcmaster Carr plastic heat set inserts Thread 6-32 Height 0.150" Small outer diameter 0.199" Large outer Diameter 0.209" Quantity 100 Part number 93365A130 $11.81
with the following soldering iron insert installation heat set tool
92160A119 Cost $14.42
http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/119/3267/=orxceo
12 3/4" bolts to match the thread inserts. Print all the parts. I used a .5mm nozzle. ABS plastic, you will need to use support for almost everything except the backplate, and there is a bunch of trimming involved. Sorry. Insert 6 threaded inserts using a soldering iron into each of the plastic springs on the "feet" Once you have everything printed and the existing printer disassembled and ready to install, you can begin by installing the acme nuts. Keep the existing nut on the rod, and place the printed plastic spring on the rod. insert the spring with the cut side up, then thread on the second nut and spin it down so the printed spring is basically sandwiched. Now, use the upper nut to compress the metal spring down to the internal stop, and thread the lower nut up as close as you can get it to the lower socket. relax tension on the spring to let the lower nut enter the socket. Now assemble the upper and lower clamp pieces for both sides, using the existing bearings and clamp hardware. Install the idler pully. Now place the spring / rod assembly in place on the clamp pieces, and secure with the 12 bolts. You may not be able to fit the bolt near the idler bolt itself, if so, don't worry, the spring is plenty stiff. You also may need to clearance the backplate on that side depending on the shape of your idler nut. Re-level and calibrate everything, then try a few Z up and down passes. If the carriage goes up and down without trying to pull off the lower nut, you have a good spring. Congratulations, you're done! Troubleshooting: if your carriage seems to be binding, try setting your threaded inserts deeper into the feet and then shaving off a bit of the feet themselves. If your metal spring seems to be too weak and the carriage is riding up on one side or the other, try a stronger spring. You may want a stiffer coupler if you are using an aluminum helix coupler.

description.text:
No Lord or Lady of the Sea should leave home without their triple-tined symbol of sovereignty.

Use it to create wells, invent the horse, slay giants, or just as a handy walking stick.

If you happen to be a child of the Sea, or a mere mortal, well... you could use it for cosplay or as a handy walking stick! (This one is probably not very good for spear-fishing.)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

High

Infill:

Default

Notes:

Print three of the tines with the tip of the tine on the build surface, and the outside curve pointing up.

The hub and cap pieces should be printed with the dowel rod opening facing down; no support structures should be created using default settings, as the roof of the opening is sufficiently angled.

Print any number or combination of rings that you like, for whatever arrangement you like.

I decided I wanted my tines, hub and cap in Glow-in-the-Dark, and to spray my dowel rod and ring pieces with golden spray paint. These are entirely personal choices.

Clean-Up

THOROUGHLY remove all the support structure and sand down all rough spots.

Pay special attention to smoothing out the faces on the tine and hub which will be sliding along each other as there is VERY little wiggle room (for a reason).

Cyanoacrylate (super glue) works well for re-affixing the little parts of tine which may break off during cleanup.

(I ran out of Glow-in-the-Dark on my last print, which included the hub and cap, and switched to transparent blue for the tops of those parts; it actually came out pretty nice!) Gather parts
  • 1 1.25" dowel rod of arbitrary length; I chose 6'.
  • 1 hub piece
  • 1 cap piece
  • 3 tine pieces
  • Some ring pieces (optional; I only used 2 small and 1 medium rings due time)
  • Fasteners (small wood screws would be best; I made do with machine screws)
Assembly

The hub and cap shapes are designed to slide onto the end of a 1.25" wooden dowel rod and be fastened in place with small wood screws. Any rings should be slid on in the desired order before fastening the ends on.

The tine shapes are designed to (after the thorough removal of support structure and a good sanding) barely slide into the hub piece after that's been fastened to the dowel, and should stay firm by friction alone.

It's time to cosplay!

• I need to experiment more with the joints between pieces. An awesome way to break free of some of the constraints of the printer. Getting these to fit just right is more difficult than I expected, and I finally settled for good enough due to time constraints.
  • Don't trust the material usage estimates in MakerWare too much when you're near the end of your spool. Or do, it might come out looking cool anyhow.

print_settings.Notes:: V1 printed in Orange eSun PLA+ because Halloween.  V2 printed in Inland Black PLA, also because Halloween.

title: Finial Tetra (for PVC Halloween Fence)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a finial for Halloween fences made from PVC pipe. This particular model is the very popular traditional Victorian four-fin delta shape.

See below for detailed instructions. In particular, be sure to take note of the "Scaling to other pipe sizes" section, as you will need to size this to the pipe you are using.

I have a collection of Halloween things to which my other finial designs are posted as I complete them.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

<= 0.3 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Layer height is not terribly important as the finials aren't usually viewed up close. I tend to print these with 0.2 mm layers.

I've found that the spindle-like built-in support (inside the pipe opening in the base) tends to stick to the build plate as you remove the part, but if it doesn't, you can break it off manually after printing if you like, or even leave it on. It should still fit inside the PVC pipe. However, note that it will be in the way if you want to secure the finial with a screw, so removing it may be desirable.

V1 printed in Orange eSun PLA+ because Halloween. V2 printed in Inland Black PLA, also because Halloween.

What is this for?

Faux wrought iron Halloween fencing can be made out of PVC pipe (see the Instructables link in the Summary section above), and is both decorative and functional (it discourages vandalism and keeps enthusiastic ToTs from traipsing straight through your yard and possibly tripping over hidden electrical wires, gravestones, and other decor).

However, the finials (decorative tops of the fence posts) are often a problem. You can order plastic finials online, but they come with square bases that don't work very well with the round PVC pipes. The usual solution is to soften the PVC with a heat gun enough to force the finial onto the end, squaring the circle of each post by essentially shaving off the curved sides. This is labor intensive and not terribly safe (aside from the heat itself, PVC is likely to give off toxic fumes when heated like this). And even then you aren't done; securing the finial usually requires drilling a hole for a screw for each post because they resist gluing.

I thought it might be better to design a finial that simply slides onto the end of the pipe and can be secured with a friction fit and is made of plastic that may be more glue-compatible. If screw holes are desired, these could be designed in (I haven't done that yet, however).

It is not terribly practical to try to individually print every finial for a run of fence. I would need to print 81 of them, just for the fence around 3 sides of the main section of my yard. As they take roughly four hours each to print on my machine, that works out to 13.5 days of round the clock printing. But you could print a few and make molds to cast them in something weather resistant (Great Stuff expanding foam, Silicone, etc.). I may create printable molds for this purpose.

Scaling to other pipe sizes

You can use the finial with either schedule 40 (white) or schedule 80 (grey) PVC. It won't matter which of these standards you use. The outside diameters are identical; only the inside diameters differ. Since the finial fits over the pipe as a cap, we only care about the pipe's outer diameter. Grey is usually significantly cheaper, but it also comes with a short bell on one end, so you lose a few inches of the length. There's also black schedule 40, which could save you some painting, but it's more expensive.

This finial was designed to fit a 3/4 inch PVC pipe, which I chose as a compromise. It's more common to use 1/2 inch PVC for the fence posts, but to use larger PVC for the ends of each section of fence. So you may need to scale the finial up or down from its default size.

The default finial is nearly six and a half inches tall. Due to cable management issues on Wanhao style print heads, I would have to mod my Z axis (e.g. AzzA's Z extensions) before I could print that height. Scaling for a 1 inch pipe would be even worse; the finial would be more than 205 mm tall, well over my Maker Select's theoretical max build height of 180 mm. "We're gonna need a bigger printer." (cue Jaws theme) Deltas and larger cartesian printers might fare better.

If you do need to scale the part for a different pipe size, though, some things to keep in mind are that 1) you are scaling to fit the model to the new pipe's outer diameter (plus a bit for tolerance), 2) the name of the pipe bears little resemblance to any actual measurement you'll get off of it, and 3) you need to compensate from the "ideal" scale factor to keep the tolerance more or less constant.

For the pipe standards mentioned above, here are a few common scales:

  • 3/4 inch pipe = The model's base has an Inner Diameter of 1.08 inches. This equals the pipe's standard outer diameter of 1.05 inches, plus a designed clearance around the pipe of 0.03 inches (a bit more than three quarters of a millimeter). That clearance seems sufficient for a relatively snug fit. Of course, printed parts have some dimensional variance depending on calibration and material, and the pipe also has some accepted variation, so Your Mileage May Vary.
  • 1/2 inch pipe = 0.84 inches O.D. The exact scaling factor from 3/4 inch to 1/2 inch pipe is 80% (0.84 / 1.05). Probably the actual number you need to scale by will be a little larger; you are shrinking the tolerance as you scale down, so the finial may not fit if you go all the way down. 81% is a good starting point as it seems to fit snugly in my tests.
  • 1 inch pipe = 1.315 inches O.D. The scaling factor from the default pipe size to this pipe is 125.24% (1.315 / 1.05). However, the actual number that you will need to scale by will probably be a bit smaller; you are enlarging the clearance between parts as you scale up, so the finial will be loose if you don't stop a bit short. (Going down to exactly 125% was still a bit loose in my latest test; you might want to work down from there.)

The easiest way to check the tolerance for yourself is to print the included test ring, scaled using the same factor you intend to use on the actual finial. You can also generate your own ring if you prefer, essentially by printing only the first few millimeters at the base of the model.

Change history

2016-07-23: The v2 file includes tapered fins to facilitate casting, and both v1 and v2 have had a spindle-like support added to the pipe opening in the base to eliminate the need for slicer-generated supports (at least on the base).

description.text:
GREEN LAB es un sistema de cultivo hidropónico que nace gracias a la investigación de diferentes problemáticas del actual sistema agrícola, alimentario y medioambiental en las ciudades y el resto del planeta.

A través de entender cómo se desarrollaba la agricultura en sus inicios hasta la modernidad, desde que se cultiva hasta que el producto es adquirido y viendo todos los procesos y problemáticas medioambientales que generan junto con la necesidad de integrar en las ciudades una atmósfera más natural para una mejor calidad de vida, nace la idea de incorporar un sistema hidropónico en el que las plantas y la agricultura formen parte del paisaje urbano.

Este sistema hidropónico tiene como objetivo adaptarse a los espacios que actualmente no tienen uso en las ciudades como terrados, solares o incluso balcones dándole un carácter más natural aportándole sus múltiples beneficios para la biodiversidad de la zona y los habitantes.

Green Lab es un sistema hidropónico compacto, apilable y adaptable a espacios exteriores e interiores con la capacidad de crear zonas verdes.

El resultado de este sistema viene dado gracias a la conexión entre Tecnología, Naturaleza y Diseño. A través de sistemas de fabricación digital y de unas instrucciones de uso, el usuario puede descargarse el archivo, fabricarlo en talleres de fabricación digital, montarlo en el lugar que se vaya a utilizar y ponerlo en funcionamiento de manera fácil y eficiente.

GREEN LAB

print_settings.Notes:: It's also probably best that you print the arms, legs, and spiky back things with a few extra shells just so you can sand them down a bit if you have to.

description.text:
It's a figure of the Pokémon Regice. Simple. I was bored and ended up making this.

The figure has two different bases. The first is more trophy-stand-ish if you want something like a Super Smash Bros. trophy. The second is an ice base.

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

KEEP IN MIND, this model is extremely small. You'll almost certainly have to scale it up a bit. Just make sure that you keep the same scale factor.

I'll warn you, the spiky back things and/or arms may not lie perfectly flat on the bed, so print those with a raft. The base and body don't need a raft, though.

It's also probably best that you print the arms, legs, and spiky back things with a few extra shells just so you can sand them down a bit if you have to.

If you used a raft for the arms, be careful not to snap the fingers off when you remove the arms.

I'd strongly advise that you use a bit of glue to hold everything together once it's done.

Since the holes in the body will be filled with supports, get a rough file to clean them out.

Sand down the arms, legs, and back things if you need to for them to fit.

description.text: Nothig special

Little things can make a big difference. You can help support the Ronald McDonald House by collecting the little tabs from aluminum cans. The funds generated from recycling these aluminum gems help offset the House's expenses. Collecting tabs can be an easy and fun project! Tabs can be dropped off at a number of different McDonald or other locations.

Many groups such as schools, corporations, clubs and communities participate in this program and it's a simple way to make a big difference. Collecting can tabs is a great program that benefits the Ronald McDonald House families and is easy to participate!

This box only consists of three parts that slide together. No tools or glue required! And thanks to its small footprint of 3.6"x 2.5", this box can be located anywhere in a kitchen, office, or other recycling areas.

description.text:
Stepper mount: Very sturdy mount of the Z stepper, way better than original.
Z-nut-fix: Not mine, downloaded and used as is.
Z-stabilizer is the most important part of this set.
Why have the Z-axis suspended in a spring? Weird... this part stabilize it. Print and mount around the shaft coupler and, voila.

comments.text: I tried using this but it made Z banding much worse.  The original mounts that come with the tarantula are quite flexible so if you have a slight bend in your rod then they will compensate for it.   These parts are really rigid so the bend in my rod is passed onto the x rail.
